items.title: job template creation with associated credentials since AWX 5.0

labels.name: modules
labels.description: related to modules in Ansible core

items.body:
I was about to create a bug in AWX until I found [this reply](https://github.com/ansible/awx/issues/4148#issuecomment-504763528) which shows it's expected behavior, but right now the ansible module `tower_job_template`, which in turn uses `tower-cli` as far as I can see, cannot create a job template with credential association anymore (it worked up until including AWX 4.0).

As stated in the linked comment, two requests are necessary, so either `tower-cli` should wrap that or the ansible module should handle this. What is your opinion on this or did I miss some progress in one of the related pieces that would tackle this issue?

There is no error on ansible module execution and the credential name is sent with the request as it used to. The job template gets created, however, it is not associated with any credentials.

My versions
AWX 6.0
tower-cli 3.3.4
ansible 2.9.dev0 (894d19b1088d8d4872ca0dd2b9588f196b9a34ea)

items.title: Package Tower api.py separately
items.body:
I’m curious to see what your thoughts are on this. 

At a cursory glance, it would appear that the code in api.py is pretty independent from the rest of the code base and pretty stable. What are your thoughts on making this a separate Python package? It would be small, but it would help prevent others from reinventing the wheel. 

I am thinking about doing some projects that would interface with Tower and having a package that wraps the api that is used by more people than just me would be very helpful. Of course, I could always have my projects depend on Tower-cli and then import api.py, but that feels less clean.

What are your thoughts here?

items.title: insecure flag raises KeyError python3
items.body:
# Issue
Using --insecure flag raises keyerror for python3 and ansible-tower-cli==3.3.4

Version 3.3.3 does not raise the error nor does it happen under python2.7

# Reproduction Steps
```
$ python3 -m venv test
$ source test/bin/activate
$ pip install ansible-tower-cli==3.3.4
$ tower-cli project modify x --insecure
```

# Expected Outcome (As with tower-cli=3.3.3)
```
Error: There was a network error of some kind trying to connect to Tower.
```

# Actual Outcome
```
  File "/home/hp/git/tower-cli/test/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 546, in get
    return self.request('GET', url, **kwargs)
  File "/home/hp/git/tower-cli/test/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/tower_cli/api.py", line 257, in request
    r = self._make_request(method, url, args, kwargs)
  File "/home/hp/git/tower-cli/test/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/tower_cli/api.py", line 142, in _make_request
    if (settings.verify_ssl is False) or hasattr(settings, 'insecure'):
  File "/home/hp/git/tower-cli/test/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/tower_cli/conf.py", line 234, in __getattr__
    if CONFIG_PARAM_TYPE[key] == click.STRING or CONFIG_PARAM_TYPE[key] == click.Choice:
KeyError: 'insecure'
```

# Fix tower_cli/conf.py (line 50)
Add insecure flag to CONFIG_PARAM_TYPE as
```
'insecure': click.BOOL
```

items.title: job_template associate_credential does not work for extra vault credential
items.body:
Using version `ansible-tower-cli-3.3.2` and in my case AWX version 3.0.1.

I wanted to add a second vault credential to a job template.

```
awx-cli job_template associate_credential --job-template myjob --credential 5
```

I get the following:

```
Error: The Tower server claims it was sent a bad request.

POST http://awxweb.service.consul/api/v2/job_templates/75/extra_credentials/
Params: None
Data: {"id": 5, "associate": true}

Response: {"error":"Extra credentials must be network or cloud."}
```

According to the docs, the `extra_credentials` endpoint was deprecated and the `credentials` endpoint within `job_templates` should be used for multiple vault support. In this case: `http://awxweb.service.consul/api/v2/job_templates/75/credentials/`. Works indeed perfectly through the AWX API.

items.title: --extra-vars defined in tower-cli call not populating variable in host field of playbook
items.body:
I have an Ansible tower Job template that has the following host line set in the root .yml file-

```
---
- hosts: "{{ env }}_web"
  remote_user: myuser
```
My inventory file has a group for dev_web, stage_web, and prod_web. 

```
[dev_web]
217.0.10.8

[stage_web]
217.0.10.9

[prod_web]
217.0.10.10
```
When calling this script through the command line, it works as expected -

`ansible-playbook "-e env=dev" playbook.yml (works as expected)`

When calling through Ansible tower (The tower-cli utility), it fails -

```
tower-cli job launch -J 46 --extra-vars "env=dev" --monitor

ERROR! The field 'hosts' has an invalid value, which includes an undefined variable. The error was: 'env' is undefined
```
Can the hosts value not be populated the same way through tower / tower-cli as it can through the command line version?

Thanks.

items.title: Unable to tower-cli send workflow that uses Workflow inventory
items.body:
When trying to use tower-cli send with a workflow I have just grabbed using tower-cli receive, I get an error:

```Failed to create new workflow node : The Tower server claims it was sent a bad request.

POST https://awx.internal.digitalocean.com/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/
Params: None
Data: {"workflow_job_template": 437, "unified_job_template": 117}

Response: {"resources_needed_to_start":["Job Template inventory is missing or undefined."]}
```

After doing some digging, this only happens if the Job Templates being setup as nodes in the workflow prompt for inventory on launch. In the web ui, we have the workflow also prompt for that inventory on launch and pass it along to all the Job Templates it runs. 

Reproduction steps:
Create a new workflow with a single Job template in it. Set both workflow and Job Template to "prompt for inventory". 
tower-cli receive --workflow "Your test workflow" > workflow.json
tower-cli send workflow.json

Tower Version: AWX 3.0.1.0 
tower-cli version: Tower CLI 3.3.3
Python 3.6.7

items.title: tower-cli does not support username with leading zero
items.body:
Here is an example, for valid user "008675309", which can log into the Tower web interface using the same password;
$ tower-cli credential list -u "008675309" -p ‘MyPassword'
Error: Invalid Tower authentication credentials (HTTP 401).

Other valid user, beginning with non zero succeeds ("481629847",) even when leading zero is added ("00481629847", which does not exist):

$ tower-cli credential list -u "481629847" -p 'MyPassword'
== ========================= ===============
id           name            credential_type
== ========================= ===============
71 aws-ansible-x                           5
74 ansible-vault-d                         3
42 empty-machine-credentials               1
== ========================= ===============

$ tower-cli credential list -u "00481629847" -p 'MyPassword'
== ========================= ===============
71 aws-ansible-x                           5
74 ansible-vault-d                         3
42 empty-machine-credentials               1
== ========================= ===============

It appears the username is being treated as a number somewhere along the pathway, even though the tower-cli code looks like it is a string.  Any patterns of quoting or escaping, or placing the same into .tower_cli.cfg do not make any difference.

This is a blocker for some automation we are trying to roll out, since several of the users who need to run CLI commands have the username with leading zero.  So far, we have not found any workaround for the issue.

items.title: tower-cli login does not support username starting with a dash "-"
items.body:
Tower CLI 3.3.2
API v2
Ansible Tower 3.4.1
Ansible 2.4.2.0

I have some generic users (used for automation) where the name starts with a dash "-" (not my idea, but a company policy). For exampe, when I run `tower-cli login '-my-id'` it fails with the following error:
```
Usage: tower-cli login [OPTIONS] USERNAME
Try "tower-cli login --help" for help.

Error: no such option: -m
```
Escaping the `-` does NOT work either as the `\` is passed to the rest call.
As a workaround, I stored the username/password in the .tower-cli.cfg. However, I would like to make use of the OAuth token (much faster subsequent cli calls).

items.title: Page Numbers incorrect when using all-pages and format human
items.body:
When ``--all-pages`` is specified with ``--format human``, incorrect page numbers are printed.

Sample:
`` tower-cli user list --all-pages``

Returns (most output snipped):
`(Page 1 of 8.)`

This appears to have been introduced [here](https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/commit/d3f2a8ba937afc11768817a74d6201bf271b6bbb).  Including 'count' broke the logic used to [calculate the current page](https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/blob/867164ed42a3a28d953cb005b70c601d874f5f20/tower_cli/cli/resource.py#L266).  Prior to this change, no page information was printed when --all-pages is specified.

items.title: role list drops --team flag when --all-pages is specified

milestone.title: release_3.3.2
milestone.description: Placeholder release for important but non-urgent fixes.

items.body:
If `--all-pages` and `--team` are specified when calling `role list` in the CLI , `--team` gets lost after the first page of results.  The first page is requested correctly from `/api/v2/teams/X/roles/`, but subsequent pages are fetched from `/api/v2/roles` .

Since 'team' is not a valid attribute for a role, [data_endpoint strips it](https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/blob/867164ed42a3a28d953cb005b70c601d874f5f20/tower_cli/resources/role.py#L177).  This works for [one-page calls to list](https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/blob/867164ed42a3a28d953cb005b70c601d874f5f20/tower_cli/resources/role.py#L306) , but [the all_pages loop ](https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/blob/867164ed42a3a28d953cb005b70c601d874f5f20/tower_cli/models/base.py#L555 ) makes list calls without the `team` field.

Here's a sample, snipped to the first 2 API calls:
```
tower-cli role list --team 8 --all-pages --verbose
*** DETAILS: Getting records. *************************************************
GET https://tower-test/api/v2/teams/8/roles/
Params: []

*** DETAILS: Getting records. *************************************************
GET https://tower-test/api/v2/roles/
Params: [('page', 2)]

```

This returns every role in the system, rather than just those for team 8.

items.title: tox: Should the py26 testenv be kept ?
items.body:
As a potential contributor, the first thing I do when starting to work on a project is run the test suite.

When I clone `tower-cli` and run `tox` I end up with:

```
docs: commands succeeded                                                  
flake8: commands succeeded                                                
ERROR:   py26: commands failed                                            
py27: commands succeeded                                                  
py34: commands succeeded                                                  
py35: commands succeeded                                                  
py36: commands succeeded   
```

They are 208 occurrences of the same failure: `ValueError: zero length field name in format`.
(ie. `prefix = urljoin(prefix, "{}/".format(CUR_API_VERSION))`)

It happens because the format expression has been used without indices. Expression that has become valid in py27+ and py32+.

Looking at `HISTORY.rst` I can see that in the notes of `3.1.8`: `Begin process to deprecate python 2.6.`

So should the py26 tox testenv be kept?

items.title: Improve documentation about usage of variables?
items.body:
I am new to tower-cli (I wanted to use it inside a python-script) and really had some struggle to understand how I am able to add variables e.g. when creating a new host.

I ended up searching through the source-code of this repo to find examples where variables get used and finally was successful by adding them to a host. 

Afterwards I was asking myself if I was the only one who did not know how to declare variables e.g. when creating hosts because there was no information about this topic in the documentation? I think everything else of the API is really intuitive or described inside of the documentation, but adding variables is not. 

I am willing to add this additional documentation infomation as a PR, but only if you think that it is a good idea. I probably would add it under "API reference/introduction".

items.title: Error when creating project as low-permissions user
items.body:
The code

https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/blob/4d146cb8b78ea055461241190f883f792c6c8d4c/tower_cli/resources/project.py#L117-L118

is founded in the assumption that POST will always be an action in the OPTIONS. This is not true if the requesting user does not have permission to create a project, and causes tower-cli to error, instead of giving a permission denied error.

items.title: Make organization a mandatory field while creating a project

labels.name: awx
labels.description: problems with awx and not tower-cli

items.body:
On UI, organization is a mandatory field for a project. You can't save the project without assigning it a organization. But tower-cli allows to create a project without organization, which in turn messes up the permission on the job templates based on that project.

You can create a project like following:

~~~
tower-cli project create -n tower-cli-project --scm-type manual --local-path test_tower_cli
~~~

This will create a project names tower-cli-project on Tower without any organization.

After this create a job template based on above project project:

~~~
tower-cli job_template create -n test-tower-cli --project tower-cli-project --playbook test_module.yml --ask-inventory-on-launch true --ask-credential-on-launch true
~~~

This creates a job template named test-tower-cli on Tower. But if you check the permission tab, there is only a Admin permission for the user who created it. All the other System Admins will not show up there. 

This is because there is no organization in the Project. Once I put an organization in the project and recreate the job templates from tower-cli, I see the right permissions.

items.title: Modify send/receive to include labels.
queries for jobs that have been running longer than N return no results

labels.name: awx
labels.description: problems with awx and not tower-cli

items.body:
Re-filing of AWX issue

https://github.com/ansible/awx/issues/1858

----

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Getting a list of jobs that are running and have an elapsed time greater than N seconds does not seem to work.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: Tower 3.2.2
* AWX install method: 
  * src: "https://releases.ansible.com/ansible-tower/setup-bundle/{{ tower_bundle }}.tar.gz"
  * command: ./setup.sh
* Ansible version:  2.4.2.0
* Operating System: Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.4 (Maipo)
* Web Browser: any

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Pasting tower-cli commands used for easiness, I get the same bevaviour if I point a browswer of my choice at `https://tower.example.com/api/v2/jobs/?&elapsed__gt=9;status=running` and `https://tower.example.com/api/v2/jobs/?&elapsed__gt=9&status=running` (unsure if *;* or *&* needed when combining the query. I'm told *;* is the correct delimiter)

(It's just easier to paste one shell session than copypasta from multiple queries in the browser)

```
[vagrant@tower ~]$ tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running                       
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
id  job_template         created          status   elapsed  
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
796           35 2018-05-08T19:30:09.076Z running 62.556298
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
[vagrant@tower ~]$ tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running --query elapsed__gt 60
No records found.
[vagrant@tower ~]$ tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running --query elapsed__gt 90
No records found.
[vagrant@tower ~]$ tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running                       
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
id  job_template         created          status   elapsed  
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
796           35 2018-05-08T19:30:09.076Z running 79.255133
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
```
```
[vagrant@tower ~]$ tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running --query elapsed__lt 10
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
id  job_template         created          status   elapsed  
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
796           35 2018-05-08T19:30:09.076Z running 88.274961
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
[vagrant@tower ~]$ tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running --query elapsed__lt 100
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
id  job_template         created          status   elapsed  
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
796           35 2018-05-08T19:30:09.076Z running 91.281971
=== ============ ======================== ======= ========= 
```

Please note that queries on non-running jobs seem to work just fine. So be sure to query for running jobs when reproducing.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
`elapsed__lt` and `elapsed__gt` should correctly compare the values (but maybe I'm just using it wrong).
* `tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running --query elapsed__gt 60` should have returned *job 796*
* `tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running --query elapsed__lt 100` should have returned *No records found.*

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
* `status=running` combined with `elapsed__gt` never returns results
* `status=running` combined with `elapsed__lt` always returns results

items.title: Add multiple Vault-type credentials on creation of new Job Template

milestone.title: release_3.3.8
milestone.description: 3.3.5 might wind up being more bug focused, so more invasive changes could get punted here

items.body:
When using `tower-cli job_template create` there is no known way to add multiple `vault-credential` to the template.  To date, I have tried multiple `--vault-credential "<cred_name>"` arguments and the template simply uses the last specified argument.  I've also tried a comma-delimited list in a single argument (e.g. `--vault-credential "<cred1_name>,<cred2_name>"`, but it errors as it cannot find a single credential matching  the combination of the names.

Given that Ansible 2.4+ supports multiple vaults, I need a method to add the vaults to the job template at create time.  The AWX GUI does allow you to specify multiple vault credentials by clicking the Search icon next to the Credential field, filtering by Vault type, and checking multiple credential items in the list.

items.title: Creating workflow using schema is very slow

labels.name: awx
labels.description: problems with awx and not tower-cli

items.body:
Creating workflow using the schema is very slow and stuck for hours at the last step. Following is the command used to create the workflow:

~~~
tower-cli workflow schema workflow_test @./flow_schema1.yaml
~~~

It gets stuck at the last step of where it tries to get details of the workflow:

~~~
*** DETAILS: Getting records. *************************************************
GET https://127.0.0.1/api/v1/workflow_job_template_nodes/
Params: {'workflow_job_template': 11230}
~~~

It eventually prints the following message roughly after an hour:
~~~

*** DETAILS: Getting records. *************************************************
GET https://127.0.0.1/api/v1/workflow_job_template_nodes/
Params: {'workflow_job_template': 11230}

- job_template: 10623
  success_nodes:
  - job_template: 10624
    success_nodes:
    - job_template: 10625
      success_nodes:
      - job_template: 10626
        success_nodes:
        - job_template: 10627
          success_nodes:
          - job_template: 10628
            success_nodes:
            - job_template: 10629
              success_nodes:
              - job_template: 10630
                success_nodes:
                - job_template: 10631
                  success_nodes:

~~~

so workflow gets created its just that its stuck for a long time at the last step.

items.title: tower-cli ignores overriding options when performing a copy operation
items.body:
tower-cli documentation says that the **copy** operation on an object (inventory, group, host, etc) requires the [id] of the object and that any further fields are used to override the old data. However, this does not work at all. The object is copied and the new name for example contains the old name plus a timestamp instead of the new name I want.

```
tower-cli inventory copy
```
This returns the following help text. By the way the help text suggests [OPTIONS] and then [ID]. This is incorrect and will not work! You need to provide the [ID] and then the [OPTIONS]. This also needs to be corrected.

```
Usage: tower-cli inventory copy [OPTIONS] [ID]

  Copy an inventory.

  Only the ID is used for the lookup. All provided fields are used to
  override the old data from the copied resource.

Field Options:
  -n, --name TEXT                 [REQUIRED] The name field.
  -d, --description TEXT          The description field.
  --organization ORGANIZATION     [REQUIRED] The organization field.
  --variables VARIABLES           Inventory variables, use "@" to get from
                                  file.
  --kind [|smart]                 The kind field. Cannot be modified after
                                  created.
  --host-filter TEXT              The host_filter field. Only useful when
                                  kind=smart.
  --insights-credential CREDENTIAL
                                  The insights_credential field.
...
```

So using the following command results in the new name being ignored.

```
tower-cli inventory list
== ============== ============
id      name      organization
== ============== ============
 2 test                 1
== ============== ============

tower-cli inventory copy 2 --name newinventoryname

Resource changed.
== =============== ============
id      name       organization
== =============== ============
 8 test @ 08:56:57            1
== =============== ============
```

I noticed when running the copy command on a group object and providing both the **name** and **inventory** overrides, the inventory is taken but the name still is created with a timestamp and the old group name.

items.title: Automatically create commands for reverse m2m associations
items.body:
Our instance group model is sad.

```
tower-cli instance_group
Usage: tower-cli instance_group [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  Check instance groups within Ansible Tower.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.

Commands:
  get   Return one and exactly one instance group.
  list  Return a list of instance groups.
```

It only has 2 boring options! Its real reason for existence is because other resources will associate with it. It would make a lot of sense to allow users to reach these commands, like `tower-cli job_template associate_ig`, from the instance_group base command. For example, `tower-cli instance_group associate_job_template`.

Since the association commands are already created on the fly from the many-to-many field type, it may be possible to automatically generate reverse association methods on the fly as well.

For example

```
tower-cli instance_group
Usage: tower-cli instance_group [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

  Check instance groups within Ansible Tower.

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.

Commands:
  get   Return one and exactly one instance group.
  list  Return a list of instance groups.

Reverse Associations
  associate_job_template
  disassociate_job_template
```

This is a real pie-in-the-sky feature, but it might be workable.

items.title: Inconsistent naming of arguments when associating labels and credentials
items.body:
```bash
$ tower-cli job_template associate_label                                                                                                                                                           
Usage: tower-cli job_template associate_label [OPTIONS]

  Associate a label with this job_template.

Local Options:
  --job_template JOB_TEMPLATE  [required]
  --label LABEL                [required]
```
vs
```bash
tower-cli job_template associate_credential                                                                                                                                               
Usage: tower-cli job_template associate_credential [OPTIONS]

  Associate a credential with this job template.

Local Options:
  --job-template JOB_TEMPLATE
  --credential CREDENTIAL
```

Apologies if there's a dupe issue but I couldn't find it. The linked job template parameter uses underscores in one association vs a hyphen in the other.

```bash
$ tower-cli version                                                                                                                                                                                
Tower CLI 3.2.1
API v2
Ansible Tower 3.2.2
Ansible 2.4.2.0
```

items.title: Tower-cli quits the monitor before getting the end of stdout
items.body:
Hello,

I'm running this command : 
tower-cli job launch -J "$TEMPLATE" -u $AWX_USER -p $PASS --monitor --diff-mode True --job-type check --tower-host $HOST

AWX 1.0.2.372
Tower CLI 3.2.1

I have this at the end of the job launch --monitor :

> TASK [FOO] ******************************
> task path: /var/lib/awx/projects/.....:84
> ok: [....] => {....}
> Error: The Tower server sent back a server error. Please try again later.
> 

I'm missing the end of the stdout :

> 
> 13K lines missing
> ...
> TASK [BAR] ******************************
> task path: /var/lib/awx/projects/.....:42
> failed: [...] (item=..) => {...}


1/ It seems that we do not go fast enough to follow in real time stdout because of a too small number of lines between two GET : 13 K lines is too much (maybe my server ?)

2/ tower-cli should wait the end of stdout before closing output or at least getting last n lines

items.title: Prompt for password interactively
items.body: Currently, it seems to be required to store the password in plaintext in the config file when using `tower-cli`. My AWX installation uses LDAP accounts for user access, and hence the passwords supplied to AWX are valuable account passwords, and we do not want them stored on disk. It should be possible to prompt for account details when required, and then cache the session token without storing the password.

items.title: Allow creation of schedules against a job template specifying an inventory
items.body:
Hi,

I would like to use tower-cli to be able to schedule runs of a job but against different inventories. It seems this is possible using the following command, but unified-job-template requires an integer which won't be easily known:

```
tower-cli schedule create --name="Schedule against inventory" --unified-job-template="5" --inventory-source="My Inventory 1" --rrule="DTSTART:20171215T000000Z RRULE:FREQ=DAILY;INTERVAL=1;COUNT=1"

Resource changed.
```

If I try this against job_template I can enter the job template's name, but the only option I have is specifying an inventory_source which ends up in an error:

```
tower-cli schedule create --name="Schedule against inventory" --job-template="Demo Job Template" --inventory-source="My Inventory 1" --rrule="DTSTART:20171215T000000Z RRULE:FREQ=DAILY;INTERVAL=1;COUNT=1"

Error: More than one unified job template fields provided, please tighten your criteria.
```

Is there another way I should be doing this? Or can a feature please be added to enable creating a schedule using either a name in unified-job-template, or inventory with job-template?

Thanks

items.body:
I am currently trying to create a job template in Tower via tower-cli, and as I need VMWare interaction I would like to add the VMWare credentials to this job.

However, if I only add the VMWare credentials I get the following error:

```
tower-cli job_template create -f id -h $TOWER_HOST -u $TOWER_USER -p $TOWER_PASSWORD -n "VMWare" --project 78 --playbook "main.yaml" --credential 7 --inventory 10
Error: The Tower server claims it was sent a bad request.

POST https://XXX/api/v2/job_templates/
Params: None
Data: {"job_type": "run", "playbook": "main.yaml", "inventory": 10, "credential": 7, "name": "VMWare", "project": 78}

Response: {"credential":["You must provide an SSH credential."]}
```

When I try to add both VMWare and SSH credentials by adding multiple --credential statements only the last one is picked up, and adding a statement like this

`--credential 5,7`

or

`--credential "5 7"`

I get the error that the credential object cannot be found.

I noticed that there is an API call to set extra credentials for a job (which is located at https://XXX/api/v2/job_templates/$JOB_TEMPLATE_ID/extra_credentials/), is it possible to add support for this in tower-cli?

items.title: secondary install breaks subsequent normal installs

milestone.title: release_3.2.1
milestone.description:
May contain some additional backward-incompatible changes regarding general improvements not related to 3.2 changes, possibly including:

 - unified job resource refactoring

items.body:
It has taken me a while to fully quantify this problem, but it seems that these steps to reproduce will suffice:

 - switch to the v1 branch
 - (not sure if necessary) install normally with `make install`
 - install secondary install with `make v1-refresh`
 - switch to master branch
 - `make clean` and `make install`

Now check with `tower-cli --version` which version is in use. Of course, 3.2.0 is expected, but 3.1.8 is returned.

Here is a gist from the install when I do it:

https://gist.github.com/AlanCoding/5fd59ec9a5e822d50878184a5cdc3c67

The entry script for `tower-cli` _does_ reference the right version.

```
cat $(which tower-cli)
#!/Users/alancoding/.virtualenvs/cli/bin/python
# EASY-INSTALL-ENTRY-SCRIPT: 'ansible-tower-cli==3.2.0','console_scripts','tower-cli'
__requires__ = 'ansible-tower-cli==3.2.0'
import re
import sys
from pkg_resources import load_entry_point

if __name__ == '__main__':
    sys.argv[0] = re.sub(r'(-script\.pyw?|\.exe)?$', '', sys.argv[0])
    sys.exit(
        load_entry_point('ansible-tower-cli==3.2.0', 'console_scripts', 'tower-cli')()
    )

```

Inexplicably, this entry script lands on the 3.1.8 version.

I'm looking into what is going on, but unclear what root cause is at the moment.

items.title: Support for cache timeout field while doing a group create
items.body:
Currently there is no field to update the cache timeout for a group. If I use something like following

~~~
tower-cli group create -n "test_group" -d "Test_group" -i "custom" --source "custom" --source-script "test" --overwrite "TRUE" --update-on-launch "TRUE" --job-timeout "10" --force-on-exists
~~~
It creates a test_group and puts the timeout: 10 under the inventory sources, but there is no field with which I can update the "update_cache_timeout".
